text: One flaw in the film is the treatment of torpedo bomber pilot Ensign George Gay.  Gay's plane was shot down and crashed into the sea in the middle of the Japanese fleet. Although his gunner did not survive the crash, Gay did.  With the help of a life vest and a seat cushion, Gay treaded water while being surrounded by Japanese ships.  (Of course the attention of the Japanese was directed mostly skyward at the time but it was still a miracle that Gay did not get plucked out of the Pacific by one of the sons of Nippon.)  Gay essentially had a wet but front-row seat from which to watch the most important naval battle of World War II.  Through some sort of miracle he was never spotted up by the Japanese. After the battle he was picked up by an American ship.   The film shows a torpedo pilot in the water witnessing the events of the battle as they unfolded but it never identifies that pilot as George Gay.  Even worse, the film fails to explain that that same pilot survived the battle.  That's a shame because Gay's story is an amazing one. Maybe the filmmakers left it out because they thought the audience would simply not believe it.   By the way, Gay survived the war and went on to be a pilot for TWA.

text: Dont listen to the critics on this movie. While the movie certainly isn't perfect, and obviously isn't Oscar material, it is a really good movie that is entertaining, well made, and does a great job remembering the heroes of Midway. The level of historical detail at times is incredible, especially the scenes regarding the Submarine USS Nautilus.    If i had to choose between an average movie with really good CGI and average acting, or a really good movie with average CGI and good acting, I'm going to choose the really good movie every time. LEt's not forget this was the largest budget for an independent movie ever, and so they didn't have alot of resources. They got incredible actors like Woody Harrelson, Dennis Quaid, Aaron Eckhart in supporting roles. Not counting Ed Skrein, Patrick Wilson, and Luke Evans. text: I initially had mixed feelings about this movie while watching it, but walked out satisfied overall. Roughly the first quarter or so of the movie is a bit hard to get into and feels cluttered and jumbled with various plot-lines, and it's not entirely clear who the main character is supposed to be, at first. It very much had a sort of panoramic scope. After that, though, the plot comes together coherently; I enjoyed the various cuts of perspective between admirals/officers (American and Japanese), code-breakers and pilots. It ended up having surprisingly memorable characters given my initial impression, and the battle scenes were overall enjoyable and properly built tension; the CGI sometimes felt transparently fake, though it was mostly forgivable given other positive aspects, IMO. The plot is rewarding and historically accurate, and takes very little liberties. It didn't feel like a schlocky popcorn film as the trailers seem to more so suggest. Also, to risk spoiling anything, an aspect of the battles that was particularly great was the utter futility that you felt when the guys were going in for bombing runs; the casualty rate + ratio of hit to miss was pretty sobering and made the more positive moments all the more satisfying. I would definitely recommend even in spite of its flaws, especially if you're already into historical war films.

text: Man, I hate what they do with 21st century CGI.  The trailer makes it look like 200 planes are diving on a carrier at once.  That's comic strip stuff.  A flight of aircraft peel off and dive in sequence, dropping in sequence, dodging anti-aircraft fire from multiple ships, to put a 500 lb bomb on target.  That is heroic stuff, regardless if the pilot is Japanese or American.  The entire reason that the Americans were successful was mostly an accident of fate, i.e. rather than torpedo bombers (low), dive bombers (high), and fighters (protection, overwatch) arriving at the same time, the torpedo bombers arrived first, and all but one was lost.  An entire squadron was lost.  However, the Japanese CAP was drawn down to near the surface of the water, while perusing the slow, antiquated, "sitting duck" torpedo bombers, so the carriers had no fighter protection when the dive bombers made their runs.   Read some history, folks.  Hope this movie is good, but it's likely that it corrupts history for a good $Hollywood Story$.  The history of the men who fought this battle was simply heroic. text: There are scenes in this trailer that seem like Hollywood sensationalism, however, some of the scenes really did happen.  Examples:  - The scene where Bruno Guido (Nick Jonas) is in the airplane on the deck shooting at a Japanese bomber, then the bomber slices the tail of the plane off as it is shot down.  That really happened, that is NOT Hollywood!!  After that attack Bruno was immediately called up to the bridge by Admiral Halsey and promoted from Aviation Machinists Mate 3rd class to 1st class.  Unfortunately, later in the battle Guido's plane was shot down.  The pilot and Bruno were picked up by a Japanese destroyer, interrogated and then, with gun shells tied to their feet, thrown over board. - A whole squadron of Dauntless dive bombers attacking one Japanese carrier, true again.  When the dive bombers finally discovered the Japanese fleet and dove to attack the pilots were so excited they all pretty much went for the same ship.  Some realized this and broke off to attack a different ship.  Also, bombers and torpedo planes do have guns that face forward for the pilot to use, they're just not the best dog fighters.  But they do have the ability to dog fight if necessary.  I will say that the ships protecting the carriers, both US and Japanese, are way too close to the carriers.  The ships did form defensive rings around the carriers but they were spread out far more then what we are seeing in the trailer/movie.  As for those who are saying the explosions look fake, may I ask what your (real world) references are to compare them too?  I have never seen a real 500 lb. armor piercing bomb explode on a ship.  The days of dive bombers and torpedo planes have long passed any of us seeing what kind of an explosion they make.  I'm sure there are a few who have commented who have seen how an air dropped bomb explodes but I'm willing to wager not as many as there are making the comments.  I am looking forward to the movie and hope to be entertained, I also hope that they do keep the Hollywood "seasoning" (as one commenter put it) to a minimum.

Surely on a Hollywood budget a Kate or a Devastator Torpedo bomber, a Val or a Dauntless dive bomber or a Zero or a Wildcat fighter can be built and flown using original paint schemes? CGI doesn’t cut it for such a pivotal battle in world history. If the US would’ve lost the Japanese would have invaded midway then Hawaii then from there it could threaten California. text: Ironic that they mention Pearl Harbor is the greatest intelligence failure in American history and it was also the greatest failure in terms of historical accuracy on film. Yes I am talking about the Micheal Bay CGI mess fest. This looks like more of that and that isn't a compliment. I love WWII period films. But Tora Tora Tora is a far better film than Pearl Harbor ever was. You know what made Tora Tora Tora, or A Bridge Too Far or hell even Gettysburg; so damned good? The use of practical effects and attention to authenticity. The B-17 that lands on one wheel in Tora Tora Tora? That was real, flown by a real pilot. The Zero that crashes into a hangar? That was real too, they launched the Zero down a chute packed with explosives. The P-40 that veers wildly and explodes on the runway after being strafed by zeroes? That was real too. It was controlled electrically.  You know the line in the trailer about "We believe the target is Midway" and we then hear "Washington disagrees." This I find hard to believe.  Do you know where the Office of Naval Intelligence was in 1943? That's right...Washington DC.   The Americans had been decoding Japanese communications since 1942. This was made evident at midway.   "Since early 1942, the US had been decoding messages stating that there would soon be an operation at objective "AF". It was initially not known where "AF" was, but Commander Joseph Rochefort and his team at Station HYPO were able to confirm that it was Midway: Captain Wilfred Holmes devised a ruse of telling the base at Midway (by secure undersea cable) to broadcast an uncoded radio message stating that Midway's water purification system had broken down.[54] Within 24 hours, the code breakers picked up a Japanese message that "AF was short on water".[55] No Japanese radio operators who intercepted the message seemed concerned that the Americans were broadcasting uncoded that a major naval installation close to the Japanese threat ring was having a water shortage, which could have tipped off Japanese intelligence officers that it was a deliberate attempt at deception."  While I don't have any records I find it hard to believe that the Commander in Chief would not be kept abreast of the situation of by his advisors and staff. Especially after the mistakes that were made at Pearl.
